questions.question_text: The atmosphere contains the following gases:
options: 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 0.03% carbon dioxide, rest rare gases
78% helium, 21% oxygen, 0.03% carbon dioxide, rest: rare gases
78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, 1% carbon monoxide, rest: rare gases

questions.question_text: The volume percentage of oxygen in the atmosphere is 21% which
options: Is constant for all altitudes conventional airplanes can reach

questions.question_text: Oxygen, combined with hemoglobin in blood is transported by
One of the most dangerous symptoms of hypoxia concerning flight safety is:
options: Impaired judgement, disabling the pilot to recognize the symptoms
Reduced coordination of limb movements, causing the pilot to spin

questions.question_text: One of the most frequent symptom(s) of decompression sickness emerging after a decompression in airline operation
options: Are neurological damages to the CNS

questions.question_text: The cabin pressure in airline operation is
What is the Time of Useful Consciousness?
options: The length of time during which an individual can act with both mental and physical efficiency and alertness, measured from the moment at which he loses his available oxygen supply
The time taken to become aware of hypoxia due to gradual decompression
The period of time between the start of hypoxia and the moment that the pilot becomes aware of it

questions.question_text: You can overcome hyperventilation by breathing into a plastic or paper bag. The Intention is:
options: To increase the amount of nitrogen in the lung
To raise the level of CO2 in the blood as fast as possible

questions.question_text: Which phenomenon is common to hypoxia and hyperventilation?
options: Tingling sensations in arms or legs

questions.question_text: The risk of a barotrauma of the middle ear is more likely to occur
The purpose of cabin pressurisation system is:
options: Reduce gastrointestinal- trapped gas-, middle ear- and sinus- problems.
To allow the crew and passengers to move about freely in a comfortable environment, unencumbered by oxygen masks or other life support equipment.

questions.question_text: Flickering light when reflected from spinning rotor blades
options: Can cause spatial disorientation and/or nausea, when looked at for a longer period of time
Should be avoided, because it may destroy the optical nerve

questions.question_text: Presbyopia is:
Scanning at night should be performed by:
options: Slight eye movement to the side of the object
Concentrated fixation on an object (image must fall on the fovea centralis)

questions.question_text: A pilot approaching a runway which is narrower than normal may feel he is at a greater height than he actually is. To compensate he may fly a
options: Flatter than normal approach with the tendency to undershoot
Higher than normal approach with the tendency to overshoot
Compensatory glide path and stall out

questions.question_text: Spatial disorientation will be most likely to occur during flight:
options: When flying in and out of clouds and the pilot maintains good instrument cross check
When flying in light rain below the ceiling
If the brain receives conflicting informations and the pilot does not believe the instruments

questions.question_text: Hypoxia will effect night vision:
What is meant by the term Incapacitation?
options: When situational awareness of the crew is too low.
The gradual or sudden loss of a crew members ability to function.

questions.question_text: In the short-term-memory, information is stored for approximately
Concerning the relation between performance and stress, which of the following statement(s) is (are) correct?
options: Domestic stress will not affect the pilot's performance because he is able to leave this type of stress on the ground
A moderate level of stress may improve performance
A student will learn faster and better under severe stress

questions.question_text: The main preoccupation in modern airline operations should be:
The elements of the SHEL model are:
The rate and depth of breathing is primary regulated by the concentration of:
Pulse rate is influenced by the following factors: 1. Adrenalin 2. Cortisol 3. Physical exercise.
Which of the following statements is true?
options: People are capable of living without stress.
Stressors accumulate thus increasing the likelihood to exhaustion.
Stressors are independent from each other.

questions.question_text: Motor programmes are:
options: rules that enable us to deal with preconceived situations
stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed only under continuous conscious control
stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control

questions.question_text: What optimises crew co-operation? 1. Sharing and common task 2. Confidence in each others capability 3. Precise definition of functions associated with each crew members role
What should a pilot do to keep his night vision (scotopic vision)?
options: Select meals with high contents of vitamin B and C
Not smoke before start and during flight and avoid flash blindness
Wait at least 60 minutes to night-adapt before he takes off

questions.question_text: Between which components is an interface mismatch causing stress due to poor cockpit design, thus leading to reduced human performance?
Which of the following sentences concerning crew performance is correct?
options: Mistakes can always be detected and corrected by the individual, hence too much practice is not needed.
The quality of crew-performance is not dependent on the arousal level of the individual.
The quality of crew-performance depends on the practice done to improve reliability.

questions.question_text: Pilots are more easily inclined to make mistakes when:
options: they are not constrained by time
they are not able to assess and control the risks involved in a situation

questions.question_text: Low levels of arousal are:
The amount of light which strikes the retina is controlled by:
Which of the following statements in regard to motivation is correct?
options: Too much motivation may result in hypo vigilance and thus in a decrease in attention
Motivation will reduce the task automation process hence performance will degrade
The learning process is vastly improved with motivation

questions.question_text: Five hours after a rapid decompression at FL 320 you experience pain in the joints. Which of following answers is correct?
options: This symptom indicates decompression sickness and will disappear with in 24 hours.
This phenomenon is treated by breathing 100% oxygen under pressure.
You should ask for medical advice (flight surgeon) since this is a symptom of decompression sickness.

questions.question_text: A high degree of cockpit automation may alter the traditional tasks of the pilots in a way, that
options: the crew always maintains situational awareness by being more alert.
the crew pays more attention to be always in loop.
the attention of the cockpit crew will become reduced with the consequence of 'being out of the loop'.

questions.question_text: Long-term memory is an essential component of the pilot's knowledge and expertise.
options: The information stored in long-term memory is always fresh and easy to retrieve.
It is desirable to pre-activate knowledge stored in long-term memory to have it available when required
The capacity of long-term memory is limited to a few weeks.

questions.question_text: The human information processing system is highly efficient compared to computers because of its
What are easily observable indications of stress?
options: Rising of the blood pressure, pupils narrowing, stabbing pain around the heart.
Perspiration, flushed skin, dilated pupils, fast breathing.
Faster, deep inhalation, stabbing pain around the heart.

questions.question_text: CRM (Crew Resource Management) training is:
options: intended to develop effectiveness of crew performance by improving attitudes towards flight safety and human relationship management.
not intended to change the individual's attitude towards other crew members.
intended to alter an individual's stress management capabilities.

questions.question_text: As a result of automation in cockpits,
options: coordination between the members is facilitated by the provision of more precise and more important information
communication and coordination call for an even greater effort on the part of the crew members
man-man communication has been significantly improved

questions.question_text: Which statement is correct?
options: Oxygen diffusion from the lungs into the blood does not depend on partial oxygen pressure.
Oxygen diffusion from the blood into the cells depends on their partial oxygen pressure gradient.
The gradient of diffusion is higher at altitude than it is at sea level

questions.question_text: A pilot after pulling out of a steep dive, moves the control column instinctively and firmly forward may suffer a:
A pilot has flown an aircraft as a Captain for 1000 hrs. With what phase of motor programme he can be associated with?
Too low a workload can:

In civil air transport, linear accelerations (Gx):- 1: do not exist; 2: have slight physiological consequences; 3: may, in the case of pull-out, lead to loss of consciousness; 4: cause sensory illusions on the pitch axis
Thinking on human reliability is changing. Human errors can be avoided. All it takes is to be vigilant and to extend one's knowledge
options: It is thought that it will be possible to eliminate errors in the near future
Human errors are now considered as being inherent to the cognitive function of human and are generally inescapable

questions.question_text: Gases of physiological importance to man are:
You can survive at any altitude, provided that
options: enough oxygen, pressure and heat is available
21% oxygen is available in the air you breath in
pressure respiration is guaranteed for that altitude

questions.question_text: Fatigue and permanent concentration
options: do not affect hypoxia at all

questions.question_text: An increase in the amount of carbon dioxide in the blood leads to:
options: a decrease of acidity in the blood
a reduction of red blood cells

questions.question_text: The total pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of the gases which compose the mixture corresponds to:
The barometric pressure has dropped to $1/2$ of the pressure at sea level at
Boyle's law is directly applicable in case of:
options: the expansion of trapped gasses in the human body with increasing altitude
the occurance of decompression sickness at high altitude

questions.question_text: Dalton's law explains the occurance of:
The respiratory process consists mainly of
options: the diffusion of oxygen through the respiratory membranes into the blood, transportation to the cells, diffusion into the cells and elimination of carbon dioxide from the body
the transportation of oxygen to the cell and the elimination of nitrogen
the transportation of oxygen to the cell and the elimination of carbon monoxide

questions.question_text: Carbon monoxide poisoning
options: is more likely to occur in aeroplanes where the cabin heat is technically supplied by coating the exhaust
is more likely to occur in aeroplanes with twin-engines because of high engine efficiency

questions.question_text: In the following list you will find several symptoms listed for hypoxia and carbon monoxide poisoning. Please mark those referring to carbon monoxide poisoning.
options: Muscular spasms, mental confusion, impairment of hearing.
High levels of arousal, increased error proneness, lack of accuracy.

questions.question_text: A pilot, climbing in a non-pressurised aircraft and without using supplemental oxygen will pass the "critical threshold" at approximately:
Breathing 100% OXYGEN will lift the pilot's physiological safe altitude to approximately:
The most dangerous symptoms of hypoxia at altitude are
To safely supply the crew with oxygen, at which altitude is it necessary to breathe 100% oxygen plus pressure after a rapid decompression?
When the pilot suffers from hypothermia (loss of cabin heating):
options: his oxygen need will not be affected
his oxygen need will be raised and his tolerance to hypoxia will be increased
his need for oxygen will be increased as long as he stays conscious

questions.question_text: "Tunnel vision" (loss of peripherical vision) can be observed if a pilot is subjected to more than:
"Grey out" can be observed if a pilot is subjected to more than:
How can a pilot increase his tolerance to +Gz?
options: Relax the muscles, ducking the head and lean upper body forward.
Tightening of muscles, ducking the head and perform a kind of pressure breathing.

questions.question_text: A passenger complains about a painful inflated belly at 8.000 feet. You advise him to: 1: unbuckle and massage the belly; 2: stand up and let go the gases out of the intestines; 3: eat less gas forming food and avoid carbonhydrated beverages before flight in the future; 4: drink a lot of water throughout the flight
In the pulmonary artery there is:
options: oxygen poor and carbon dioxide rich blood
oxygen poor and carbon dioxide poor blood
oxygen rich and carbon dioxide rich blood

questions.question_text: The transfer of carbon dioxide from the blood to the alveoli can be described by:
Some hours after a rapid decompression at FL 300 you experience pain in the joints. Which of following answers is correct?
options: This symptom indicates decompression sickness and will disappear when you take some exercise.
You should ask for medical advice since this is a symptom of decompression sickness.
This phenomenon is treated by breathing 100% nitrogen.

questions.question_text: Which symptom does not belong to the following list:
Which of the following statements is correct?
options: Hearing is the sense which collects most information in man
70% of information processed by man enters via the visual channel
40% of information processed by man enters via the visual channel

questions.question_text: Adaptation is
options: the adjustment of the crystalline lens to focus light on the retina
the change of the diameter of the pupil
the adjustment of the eyes to high or low levels of illumination

questions.question_text: Scanning at night should be performed by:
options: slight eye movements to the side of the object
concentrated fixation on an object (image must fall on the fovea centralis)

questions.question_text: To prevent the "autokinetic phenomena", the following can be done:
options: fixate the source of light, first with one eye, then with the other
look sideways to the source of light for better fixation
look out for additional references inside and/or outside the cockpit using peripheral vision also

questions.question_text: The time an eye needs to adapt fully to the dark is about:
The part(s) of the eye responsible for night vision
Empty field myopia is caused by:
The human ear is capable of perceiving vibrations between the frequencies
What is understood by air-sickness?
options: A sensory conflict within the vestibular system accompanied by nausea, vomiting and fear
An illness caused by evaporation of gases in the blood
An illness caused by an infection of the middle ear

questions.question_text: Approaches at night without visual references on the ground and no landing aids (e.g. VASIS) can make the pilot believe of being
options: lower than actual altitude with the risk of ducking under
lower than actual altitude with the risk of overshooting
higher than actual altitude with the risk of landing short ("ducking under")

questions.question_text: Orientation in flight is accomplished by 1: eyes; 2: utriculus and sacculus; 3: semicircular canals; 4: Seat-of-the-pants-Sense
options: 1,2, 3 and 4 are false, only 1 is correct

questions.question_text: What can a pilot do to avoid "Flicker vertigo" when flying in the clouds?
options: Dim the cockpit lights to avoid reflections
Engage the autopilot until breaking the clouds

questions.question_text: During flight in IMC, the most reliable sense which should be used to overcome illusions is the:
options: visual sense, interpreting the attitude indicator

questions.question_text: It is inadvisable to fly when suffering from a cold. The reason for this is:
options: the tissue around the nasal end of the Eustachian tube is likely to be swollen thus causing difficulty in equalising the pressure within the middle ear and the nasal/throat area. Pain and damage to the eardrum can result, particularly during fast descents

although the change in air pressure during a climb at lower altitudes is very small, it increases rapidly at high altitudes. If the tissue in the Eustachian tube of the ear is swollen, gentle descents at high alltitude would result in damage to the ear drum
swollen tissue in the inner ear will increase the rate of metabolic production resulting in hyperventilation

questions.question_text: The metabolisation of alcohol
options: is quicker when used to it
can be influenced by easy to get medication

questions.question_text: The first stage in the information process is
Motor programmes are:
options: stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed without continuous conscious control
rules that enable us to deal with preconceived situations
stored routines that enable patterns of behaviour to be executed only under continuous conscious control

questions.question_text: Which of the following human error rates can be described as both realistic and pretty good, after methodical training
Acute stress quickly leads to
options: a decrease in the amount of resources mobilized to face the situation
a state of over activation beyond the control of willpower
the mobilizatioan of resources required to cope with the stressor

questions.question_text: In a complex task high levels of arousal
If during flight a pilot is in a mental condition of "optimum arousal" he/she will be:
options: unprepared to handle a difficult situation
prepared best to cope with a difficult task

questions.question_text: Experiencing stress depends on:
options: the individual interpretation of the situation
the fragility of individuals to certain types of stimulation

questions.question_text: What is the effect of tiredness on attention?
options: It increases the ability to manage multiple matters
It leads to one's attention being dispersed between different centres of interest
It reduces the ability to manage multiple matters

questions.question_text: In order to completely resynchronise with local time after zone crossing, circadian rhythms require
options: about one week per 2.5 hours of time shift
less time when flying from east to west
about one day per 2.5 hours of time shift

questions.question_text: During paradoxical sleep
options: rapid eye movements can be observed
the tone of the muscles is similar to that in the waking state
the rhythm of the heart is very regular

questions.question_text: The physiological rhythms of a pilot in a new time zone will resynchronise to this new time zone at a rate of about
The duration of a period of sleep is governed primarily by
options: the point within your circadian rhythm at which you try to sleep
the amount of time you have been awake
the number of points you have in your 'credit/deficit' system

questions.question_text: A high degree of cockpit automation may alter the traditional tasks of the pilots in a way, that
options: it is guaranteed that the crew maintains always situational awareness
the attention of the cockpit crew will become reduced with the consequence of 'being out of the loop'
the crew can pay more attention to solve the problem in an abnormal situation without monitoring the automatic systems

questions.question_text: Which of the following drawbacks are associated with automation? 1: Reduced in manually controlling the aircraft; 2: Increased likelihood of slips while programming automatic systems; 3: Difficulties in adapting to the use of a sidestick; 4: General decrease in technical reliability
Attitudes are defined as:
options: tendencies to respond to people, institutions or events either positively or negatively
the conditions necessary for carrying out an activity

questions.question_text: Disturbance of the biological clock appears after a: 1: bad night's sleep; 2: day flight Delhi-London; 3: day flight Delhi-Colombo; 4: night flight London-Delhi
Flying from Bengaluru to Moscow you will have a lay-over of 4 days. What time measure is relevant for your circadian rhythm on the 3rd day?
Decompression leads to:
options: Release of Nitrogen bubbles in the body

Depth in vision is achieved through:

Types of Hypoxia are:
